message_1: Suppose you have a complex function $f(z) = \frac{1}{z^2-1}$ which is analytic on $\mathbb{C}$ excluding the interval $[-1,1]$. Find the value of $\text{Res}_{z=-1} f(z)$ and $\text{Res}_{z=1} f(z)$ using analytic continuation.
message_2:
To find the residues of the function $f(z) = \frac{1}{z^2 - 1}$ at the points $z = -1$ and $z = 1$, we first factor the denominator:

$$f(z) = \frac{1}{(z - 1)(z + 1)}$$

Now, we can see that $f(z)$ has simple poles at $z = -1$ and $z = 1$. To find the residue at each of these poles, we can use the formula for the residue of a simple pole:

$$\text{Res}_{z=z_0} f(z) = \lim_{z \to z_0} (z - z_0) f(z)$$

For $z = -1$:

$$\text{Res}_{z=-1} f(z) = \lim_{z \to -1} (z + 1) \frac{1}{(z - 1)(z + 1)} = \lim_{z \to -1} \frac{1}{z - 1}$$

$$\text{Res}_{z=-1} f(z) = \frac{1}{(-1) - 1} = \frac{1}{-2}$$

For $z = 1$:

$$\text{Res}_{z=1} f(z) = \lim_{z \to 1} (z - 1) \frac{1}{(z - 1)(z + 1)} = \lim_{z \to 1} \frac{1}{z + 1}$$

$$\text{Res}_{z=1} f(z) = \frac{1}{1 + 1} = \frac{1}{2}$$

So, the residues of the function $f(z) = \frac{1}{z^2 - 1}$ at the points $z = -1$ and $z = 1$ are $\text{Res}_{z=-1} f(z) = -\frac{1}{2}$ and $\text{Res}_{z=1} f(z) = \frac{1}{2}$, respectively.
